So having worked for an environmental consulting company for decades, the time mark 22:41 concerns me.  Popcorn ceilings that were built before 1990 have a high chance of containing asbestos.  Pushing the sub into it and breaking some off makes it "friable " and airborne and makes it a serious exposure risk.  Now a single incident is not likely to cause mesothelioma, but still.

OK Destin,  you may need to go back.  You said at one point that you were ready to continue on to the Pacific.  When I was a teen in the late eighties I had the opportunity to go out on a cruise in a nuclear fast attack sub.  Heading on to the ship I had one question I wanted the answer to.  When I had the chance to meet the captain I presented my question..."When a nuclear sub is transiting the north pole submerged you can steer north until you reach the pole.  But once you are there your compass just spins, any where you steer is south.  How do you know where to go?"  He looked at me for a few seconds and then said, "I don't know."  He took me to the navigator and asked him.  The answer, "I don't know."  Even as a kid I could see that they had never thought about it and felt a little silly not knowing the answer.  We asked several other people until finally we opened a door to a room not much larger than a phone booth.  There was a man standing in there, I don't know what his tittle was, and we presented my question.  He had the answer and it was quite a simple one.  Maybe things are different now but I remember thinking at the time that if I was on a sub going over the pole, whether I was the cook or the captain,  I would want to know the answer to that question.  And I certainly would want more than one person on the ship to know.  Maybe it was theatrics for a kid but they had no way of knowing I was going to ask that question.  I will tell you the answer if you want to know but perhaps you already know or can find out and make another video.

11:45 I love the little humble smile that the crew members gave him when Destin asked that question.

I'm surprised this isn't all computerized.

All the vector math, instrument monitoring, and balancing control, could all be handled very efficiently by software.

You could even get it to where the whole sub control is handled by a single pilot with a HOTAS type setup.

It would also be very possible to have a VR headset wired up, that allows the user to look right through the sub walls and Ocean darkness, to see sonar data drawn as visible objects - at real scale, in real time, at the real locations, with depth perception, and HUD overlay information. So you can literally look all around without a periscope, potentially even while piloting the sub.

And this sounds like a sci-fi movie, but it's all VERY possible today.

ETC (SS/IDW) Retired Hooyah!  Though being 6'5" in a career on submarines isn't that great for the body.  Sleep deprivation does a number to the body.  Lucky to get 2-3 hrs in a 24 period, even though we run on 18 hr days.  Never awake at the same time each day.  Sundays we tried to get less maintenance in, etc., so could get 5 hrs.  I mean in both of those times, that is the time you get to clean up, eat, and pass out asap.  Always a different time.  So many surgeries, back x3, shoulders, knees, etc.  But I wouldn't go back and change anything other than over doing it to excel in promotion potential.

FYI, Destin. TLDs (Thermo-Luminescent Dosimeters) are no longer in use by the DoD. They weren't when you uploaded this video; but most TLD(OSL) consumers haven't been given modern equipment training yet.

You probably wore an OSL (Optically Stimunlated Luminescence) device to monitor your radiation.

Love the video!

I am shocked the Navy allowed a civ on an active sub.

I tell you one thing, if I was twenty something and trying to figure out my career, this would look like an awesome life experience that you could never get at a university. If, after sub duty, you can still go to college on the GI. This opens up doors inside and outside the military.

What I recalled is the asvab scores needed to be high. I didn't study at all, just showed, got a 89. It wasn't difficult. Easier than an ACT for college (or SAT I would guess, didn't take that one), but the same style. You just need to be a little sharper than most.

At the recruiter's office, this is when they will show you these "fun" videos. They want you coming out ready to sign. At my time, they had a big sign on bonuses to seal the deal. Get through AIT, and a fat check for thousands shows up after your "normal" funds. If this still applies today, it is tempting. You'll find your bank account with more than you know what to do with.

If you want this life, there a world of unclassified information. And pictures worth thousand, right?

Understand there is a little more about life, and more so with life on a sub. Many of the men you seen, have a wife and a few little ones at "home". The wife's get used to hanging out with other navy wives, and the kids get used to daddy missing holidays and birthdays, while he does "his job". That's military life. Some grew up with this and it is normal. But it takes a special kind of relationship with the wife's/SO. Strong bond of trust. And then you come home, the special first moments with your kids are a tear jerker. And a huge flood of them telling about their lives. Just reconnecting. wife's/SO waits for her time to reconnect. But, after a few months, this will be followed with another sad goodbye. Then you refocus on your job. "home" goes into their routine.

This is an awesome career if you are offered the chance. I recommend to do it. It is hard work, but you will learn teamwork. You will learn the Navy top technology. Which will never be spoken. If you decide, afterward your tour, not be your path, you will walk away with so much more. Or, you decide to sign up a another boat or two, and you could be sitting at the XO table.

Unless things have changed in submarines in the last 30 years you have it wrong about ballast tanks. Ballast tanks are, or should be, void of air when operating submerged. Their sole purpose is to provide buoyancy in order to float the ship. Trim tanks are used to control the submarine's buoyancy when submerged; overall trim, fore and aft trim and list. Water is pumped around and out to sea, and flooded in to control these. This is the job of the Diving Officer and the Ballast Control Panel Officer. The trim tanks are hard tanks, able to be exposed to full sea pressure. The ballast tanks are always open to the sea via vents on the bottoms. Air inside the ballast tank is detrimental as it compresses and causes instability because the deeper you go the heavier you get. Occasionally the Diving Officer will order that the ballast tank vents (top vents) be cycled if he feels there might be air inside from air leakage (from the ballast tank blow valves).

The deeper you go, the more pressure is exerted on you. You can adjust to be neutrally bouyant at 66 feet (3 atmospheres in salt water), but you quickly become negatively bouyant as you descent deeper if you don't constantly add air. The steadily decreasing bouyancy effect can be alarming when first doing deep dives, the increasing pressure compresses air pockets such as your lungs and the air cells in you neoprene wetsuit.
The Yuri Lipski GoPro video of his fatal dive in Dahab's blue hole here on YouTube is an excellent example of a runaway loss of bouyancy control.

G'day from Australia, Dustin.   I'm a navy fan,  I love learning about navy things.   I thought i knew a reasonable amount about what it's like in a submarine.   And I've watched "Hunt for Red October" more than once.   What i must thank you for is  getting yourself into that submarine and for getting footage that shows us what it's like for real,  but without treating us like we're grade school children (which is how these sorts of things often turn out).     You were half expecting to be treated with a lot of caution and skepticism by the Navy, and I'd have thought that was normal.  But no.   You hit on the magic ingredient, I think.   You worked on your relationships with everyone in the navy you came in contact with and as a result they treated you as an adult, and trusted you not to get them all into strife over blabbing too much.     I am in awe of how well you trod that fine line between poking your nose into every little corner  and  keeping away from things they need to keep classified.      What you ended up with is a more comprehensive and fascinating view of submarine life and operations than I've ever heard of or seen.    That represents skill on your part for managing the technical aspects of movie making,  as well as all the relatiohships that could easily have turned sour at any moment with a poorly chosen word on your part.     And your explanations throughout both disguised edits where there was material they didnt want shown and helped me understand what was going on.       You are indeed amazingly clever and I am in awe at what you've accomplished.     Thank you.     MY life is enriched because of you.

The most impressive thing to me, who has experience in the classified realm, is that you managed to gain permission for this. Even if you have the clearance, simple security procedures mean that you need to secure permission to experience something like this and filling out a lot of paperwork. Especially during any kind of operation, whether it be an exercise or other operation, and not one of those times where they open such things to the public (where the crew is not only the best at what they do, but the entire thing is highly rehearsed to minimize spillage of classified information. That you were given permission to record is simply phenomenal. And I won't ask about the NDAs you had to sign, and the editing done by the Navy to protect OPSEC is expected. Good of you to accept it and very good of you to explain to those of us watching in case we don't know about that.

You know, maybe I should not be as impressed as I am, outside of your getting permission for it, as our armed forces are fully happy in demonstrating things. Yes, it is sanitized for OPSEC and keeping actual capabilities secret purposes, but it's still cool to see.

My wife's oldest brother-in-law was in the submarine service during the 1950s. He was an electrician's mate on board the U.S.S. Grouper, a diesel electric WW2-style submarine. He was so proud to have been a part of the "Silent Service." Up until his health failed, he attended every annual reunion of the Grouper's crew. The training the Navy gave him set him up for a decades-long career with Bell Telephone. He started out as a pole climber and finished his career in a regional switching center. He passed away last year, but I couldn't help but think of him as I watched this video. We often talked about the remarkable transition from diesel-electric to nuclear subs. One of the things he found amazing was the amount of room in the new nuclear boats compared to the claustrophobic shell he and his mates lived and worked in!
This is pretty cool stuff.  I like it.  I can see how it would be unsettling though, not being able to physically see, and relying on gauges and sensors.

Well, if the Nautilus could do this in the 1950's, punching through the Artic ice is not really the "latest cool thing" that came out. As for how they know where the ice is thin enough to punch through, isn't that a "secret de Polichinelle" as the French call it, a secret that is no secret at all ? Just googled, and that told me:

 allows the crew to locate the ice canopy in relation to the sub and find patches of open water or areas of minimal thickness. "We can tell with the sonar how far the ice protrudes down," Aljilani said. "While we can surface, there's a maximum amount of ice we can surface through.

How many countries have that capability ? Do Russian, English, French... atomic submarines can all do this ? I remember from my early 1990's study about the American strategic nuclear forces that they kept a number of nuclear subs on a rotation basis under the ice, because the noise caused by the cracking of the ice made them somewhat aucoustically stealthy... It's a beautiful sight to see them surfaced like in the movie "Ice station Zebra", but I have to admit, having to live for months under the surface of the water wouldn't be my dream job....

@SmarterEveryDay When you were speaking of the problems caused by current moving the boat in an unwanted direction, I was thinking of an airplane landing in a crosswind.  I've seen planes flying almost sideways until the last moment. Even while moving the boat in a vector between two points, or flying in the same way, you have to account for cross current.

Obviously, these processes could be handled much more effectively, accurately, and safely, if they were managed by a computer rather than human... so why aren't they? We have military aircraft whose negative stability make them impossible to be flown by a human,  so that is managed by a flight computer. Why isn't that same methodology employed here? Instead we got a guy with a 1960s mechanical stopwatch doing time distance calculations. LOL

As a scuba diver, your Cartesian diver concept comes into play as a diver descends. People always ask, “how long will your air last?” It depends on your depth. To maintain neutral buoyancy at depth will require a great intake of air to maintain the same bubble size. If you had the capability to add air to the Cartesian diver as you squeezed the bottle, your diver would maintain the same depth in the bottle. Hence, that said, to maintain neutral buoyancy at 10 meters would be 10 times greater than if you were at 1meter. Subsequently as the diver ascends, the air in the ballast tanks, (lungs) needs some place to go as the volume would continue to increase. That is the primary reason why we teach to never hold your breath while diving.
We also have an additional ballast tank which we call the BCD, buoyancy control device. Maintaining attitude at depth can be quite difficult at depth. As with the submarine you cannot just increase the pressure in the living space, we add air to the balloon on our back (BCD) to help maintain neutral buoyancy. But, as we ascend we need to bleed air from the BCD, and our lungs to control our ascent, and to be able to tweak our depth (neutral buoyancy) once e have ascended to our desired depth. Once on the surface, in a sub, they would blow all remaining water, the scuba diver would add air to the BCD.

How thick is the ice above?  I did an Ice run on a 637 class submarine in 1976.  We had a transducer mounted in the top of the sail.  You know your depth so you know the surface. Think of it as an upside down fathometer pinging on the underside of the ice.  So the difference between the ping return and the surface is the thickness of the ice.  Every time we found an area suitable area to surface we plotted the Lat and Long  to have a place to surface in case of an emergency.  Great job on your series.

I don't have that piece of information about where is the thin layer of ice, but I can imagine a technique that uses the ultrasound scanning.

It goes like this, you shoot the wave upwards and you will get TWO reflections, the first is from the inner skin if the ice, the second is from the upper skin of the ice.

of course you must apply correction factors for the propagation through water( temperature corrected) and the ice itself.
Ultrasound scanning is very amazing, you know it is used in the medical field.
you might use radio waves with exact same theory.
I wouldn't be surprised if image processing is used as well by determining how bright or dim is the ice above you.

That string drooping had NOTHING to do with AIR pressure in the sub, it started drooping because the sides of the sub it was attached to were LITERLALLY being compressed inward making the inside of the sub literally smaller. The hull tensile strength of the Titanium Alloy 6A1-4V used in the construction of most subs is at about 120,000 PSI, so in order for the hull to compress, there have got to be some SERIOUS pressure on the outside of the sub, someone could actually figure out an approximation of their depth simply by calculating the amount of pressure needed in order to compress the hull to make that string droop, just saying...lol

I may be biased, being an ex-submariner. (78 to 87 boomer class subs). Later onto NOTU, (Naval Ordinance Test Unit), we tested the subs out of the shipyards and test fired missiles and torpedo's and took them thru a test drive, maxing out the abilities.

Coolest time of my life, but, then, it was still called the 'Silent Service'. My parents, brother and sisters, my wife and kids, my friends asked what I did. Could not say. Silent Service.

So I am very impressed that the Navy allowed as much as they did. About time they allowed an honest review of what it was like on a sub.

Besides that, about your videos. I like that you actually explain what is going on. And to wear the Dolphins, you needed to know the basics of every system on the sub. That is why the sailors all sounded knowledgeable, they are.

It is a pure volunteer service, and not easy to get in.

I subscribed and will look forward to more videos, keep up the good work.

The crew of the ships / subs are consummate professionals, they must have a deep and technical knowledge to operate with the skill demonstrated in this series. It's fascinating to learn about.  There is no way not to have great respect for what they do, it is an incredibly challenging job that requires a HUGE sacrifice.  It's not easy living in those conditions and being away from your family / loved ones for so long, and under such conditions of isolation.  I disagree with a lot of what the US military is asked to do around the world, especially when it comes to the interventions / occupations of iraq and afghanistan.  I absolutely hate to see all of the hard work and wealth and LIVES squandered in unnecessary conflict.  However, I also do believe and acknowledge that the navy and in particular, nuclear submarines, serve a necessary purpose.  Without nuclear submarines, America is less safe, because they form a vital part of nuclear deterrence.  And I really do believe that nuclear deterrence is probably one of the few key factors preventing another world war.  With all that said, I wish that the US would refrain from engaging in immoral or unjustified conflicts around the world in the future, and stay focused on defending the homeland.

Previous 688 class and older submarines have fair water planes mounted on the sail instead of bow planes and they have to be put in A vertical position before breaking through the ice. The don't retract like bow planes and they don't have quite as much control because they're not as close to the bow, but I believe they stabilize the boat better at shallow depths.

Somebody needs to get their scuba certification. I don't remember open water and rescue and divemaster, but at some point along the path to dive instructor you'll learn these concepts but they don't really make sense unless you're controlling your body's ability to float or sink with your own lungs. It's one of two reasons the most important rule in diving is to exhale while ascending. It not only prevents a positive feedback loop from going out of control it also keeps your lungs intact.

But, really, my point is: go diving. At some point it becomes intuitive the way walking is or riding that goofy reverse bicycle became to you. Our brains are amazingly plastic.

One of the ways they know how to punch through the ice is by a spotter on the surface placing a pinger where the ice meets optimal conditions for this evolution when working with SPECOPS units. You can see this demonstrated in the Stargate: Continuum movie where they do just that when extracting a SPECOPS unit and the special features of that movie document this with actual footage of the exercise both on and off the sub. This included a dive team in the water filming the sub punching through from the ocean perspective and a team filming it punch through from the surface perspective, and some of it made it in the movie as well as the captain and crew of USS Alexandria (SSN 757) were extras during ICEX-07 from 23-29 March 2007 around Prudhoe Bay, Alaska.

Surface ships have expansion joints that allow the ship to expand and contract similar to subs and bridges; also the pipe fittings, wiring harnesses, etc. (fuel/water lines, fire mains, etc.) at those joints are flexible instead of rigid to allow the full range of expansion without any damage. Without these expansion joints the ship would incur structural damage due to temperature variations because metal expands in hot climates and retracts in cold climates and ships are constantly going between those two regions all the time.

On the bridge of a surface ship it's strictly business as well especially during restricted maneuvering when leaving/entering port, CONREP (connected replenishment) evolutions, and flight operations. I've got to see first hand with 20 years in the Navy and 15 years with Military Sealift Command (U.S. Navy's civil service logistics fleet auxiliary) and the professionalism and attention to detail is astounding by both bridge teams.

Thank you for this series! It was so much fun to see into the place that my son will be living very soon. He is an Ensign and currently going through the Naval Nuclear Prototype Command. He will be one of the Nuke Officers on one of these boats in less than a year.
He too is a Mechanical engineer. He went to Colorado School of Mines. All of that training he is using every day as he goes through the single hardest academic program in all of the DOD. He is done with the book learning part of the training and is now onto the Prototype part of the program where he gets to play around with a working reactor on a decommissioned ballistic missile sub, the USS Daniel Webster, SSBN 626.
He will be done with the nuke training at the end of the year and then onto Sub School. After that e will finally get to his first boat.
We are incredibly proud of him!

The part of your video about the dosimeter was interesting. My son also has to wear one of these. Here is something else.  The whole time the DOOW (Diving Officer of the Watch) is trying to figure all this stuff out, we are either making water (drinking water) which is taking seawater and bring it on board and purifying it and putting it in tanks, which is essentially ballasting the ship (Luckily at a pretty standard rate) but while he is trying to calculate a hover, we are dynamically changing his hover in the ER and he has to compensate for it.  Not to mention the bomb (O2 generator) and scrubbers as covered in prior episodes sending waste overboard - plus sanitaries and bilge tanks in the engine room - which is all coordinated thru the dive - all of that has to be accounted for in addition to the trim (what the act of getting a hover is called)  New boats like the toledo have computers and stuff to do alot of those calculations for the crew - older 637's that I was on, was all manual - DOOW did those calculations in his head using thumbrules and seat of the pants experience.

I’ve talked to an old submariner a bit. There’s something called a trim party. If the crew thinks an officer needs, shall we say, a bit of seasoning, they’ll have a trim party when the officer is in charge of trim. They’ll casually and gradually congregate at one end of the boat, wait a while, and then gradually and unobtrusively off watch crew members will move one at a time to the other end.  I learned other closely guarded secrets as well, including how to get kicked out of a bar called Marie’s, which probably isn’t there any more.
Thanks for doing this Destin, and allowing the rest of us to learn a little bit about submarines.

Retired Submariner here.  Just to clarify, they may cycle the ballast tank vents and maintain some air at different points during the diving process to control decent when working in that environment.  But, they NEVER leave air in the ballast tanks.  Trim tanks (different tanks onboard) are used to bring on and take off weight (water).  Just as you explained and for obvious reason, you would never want a submarine to get heavier (less buoyant) the deeper it goes.

20:15 somewhat ironically most of the lowest radiation places on earth are inside the outer shielding of nuclear reactors. Makes sense if you think about it, but its a little counter-intuitive. Obviously the inner shielding has to stop all the radiation from the reactor, and the outer shielding has to do the same in the case of an accident, works just as well keeping natural radiation out.
(One of the things we learned touring HiFAR, an Australian research reactor now replaced by OPAL. If you ever get the chance to gaze into a spent fuel pool, do it, the Cherenkov glow is unforgettable).

My dad was a CWO-4 in the Air Force and one of his duty stations was Hickam A.F.B. , Hawaii. As a dependent I was lucky enough to have many of the perks that come with it. There are negatives too but not enough to cry about.
I was often out fishing behind the officers club witch butts up to the mouth of Pearl Harbor, we lived on 3rd Street for those of you in the know. Waiting for a bite at the end of the line as all fishermen know can try one's patience so sometimes I puddled around with debris that was scattered along the shore. I often made little sail boats from pieces of styrofoam and stick, pieces of wood and fabric, what ever floated out of the navel base. One day I had made a sail boat from a piece of styrofoam about the size of a 1' x1' , a stick and a piece of canvas as the sail and set it off to let the wind take it away.
Not long after launch it was moving through the water quite well and thought that it stood a good chance of making it across to the other side. So many of my sailing ships sunk usually after the wind blew them over. But this one was moving along just fine and then I saw something that might change the passage of my ship.
Here comes a full grown, black and daunting nuclear submarine arriving in the harbor. That is a sight to see, and I have seen many but I'm always impressed, pure power !
As the sub came closer and my sailing ship was moving steadily across Pearl Harbor it became obvious that the two were going to make contact and with a smooth ride my sailing ship perched itself right up on the bow of that gigantic submarine !
I felt like I had accomplished something. Off it went with the sub and I never saw it again.
End of Story.

I love this series for reasons you will see at the end of my comment. BUT, the ballast tank comment (as demonstrated with the eye dropper in the bottle) is NOT TRUE!!! When submerged, the main ballast tanks, which are out side the the pressure hull, are completely full of water. Therefore there is no compression of air because there is no air. Positive and negative buoyancy (and forward and aft balance) are achieved using tanks inside the pressure hull. Just so you know what I'm talking about, I served 27 years on submarines and did tours on 6 different fast attack submarines and was Chief of the Boat on the last one.
Rock Hudson, Ernest Borgnine and Jim Brown already explained this to me.

I bet they are using sonar to measure the ice thickness. Speed of sound in water is ~1481m/s, in ice ~1826m/s and 300-950m/s in snow. Probably close enough for energy transfer between water and ice while different enough for clear boundary echos. Due to close distances maybe they are using high frequencies with very short ping time to reduce dark distance - Or even pseudonoise correlation techniques.

Right around 23:30, the CO talks about a guy walking around throwing off the buoyancy. We used to do that with 10-15 guys at a time, on purpose. It was called a trim party and was great fun (only done in open water haha). Quickly moving a thousand pounds or so would make the boat tip easily because the guy managing buoyancy (the COW) couldn’t keep up.

* QUESTION ABOUT THE SAIL, THE ENTRY COMPARTMENT AND TEMP, HUMIDITY DIFFERENTIALS OUTSIDE VS INSIDE THE SAIL/ENTRY COMPARTMENT FOR A SPECIFIC REASON WHICH I WILL MENTION BELOW @ the "!!!HERE IS MY QUESTION!!!" notation below...

DESTIN, as a FELLOW ALABAMIAN (WDE by the way), I'm curious what a guy from Alabama (albeit a well-traveled and experienced one) initially was thinking, feeling (beyond the cold) or processing from all of the philosophical, emotional, spiritual, enthusiastic aka fired up, curiosity perspectives, etc the moment you were out of the plane, out of camp, in the elements, not focusing on videoing or narrating, even if only for a few seconds or perhaps a minute to stand undisturbed, to absorb the vastness which surrounded you to the horizon which encircled you...I can only imagine the range of thoughts, emotions, contemplations, curiosities, etc which were racing through you...like I said, I can not imagine ever being is such an environment...yet, considering 1 man standing in the midst of it all must have been truly awe-inspiring in so many ways...

HOWEVER, perhaps the reality was much less pronounced than all of the grandeur thoughts I had...perhaps you were forced to have tunnel vision, a single mission, focused on one thing and one thing only...as it hits you...saying to yourself, "Oh no...please no...why now...why didn't I "go" when I was recommended to...geez...hope I make it to the sub...why am I sweating and why do I have the chills...oh no...cmon, c'mon just Hold it...Hold it...I can make it...geez people hurry up...I haven't "gone" since left the mainland..."...which was the motivation & inspiration behind focusing on such a subject as part of this series...!!!

!!! HERE IS MY QUESTION !!!...in all of my years (more than 50) I have never heard the term "sail" used to describe that area of a sub. I've heard the term conning tower used but never "sail"...Due to you having to climb up the sail only to navigate down a ladder once atop of the sail to enter inside of the sub... while layered like the little brother in The Christmas Story...it sparked a thought QUESTION...since the hatch on the sail was opened to allow people out and back in...realizing the compartment is secured and would assume airtight doors were closed while the hatch was open...I also assume the air temp inside the sail's compartment or entry compartment was sub-zero but temps no were as cold as they were outside of the sub...realizing hot air rises and again I assume the humidity levels within the sub are well controlled including having humidity within the sail's entry compartment...I'm curious why did not see or notice any venting of steam or heat coming from the hatch or anywhere in that area...had it all escaped, dissipated..is the outside temps simply too cold...just curious why no "steaming" from clothing or the "metal" itself... I probably made absolutely no sense but hopefully been around us Aubs enough will be able to decipher...

PS. I thought the iconic "DIVE" horn being broadcast was really cool...I can not imagine what the young men in subs during WWII endured...

At 15:20 If someone is really motivated, you can use the oscillation of the string in respect to the timing of the recording of the footage to make a rough guess of how wide the internal part of the submarine is.

Using the oscillation it will give you a rough idea how much the sub has deformed by comparing the oscillation of the sub when it was on the surface. Once you determine the width, you can cross refence again to a material science book and just start experimenting hydrostatic load through simulation to get a final width and match that to the deformation that allowed the string to oscillate that the same rate in the video.

Additionally, you'll need to account for various frame rates that the footage was probably recorded in.

Destin, thank you so much for making this series. After growing up in South Mississippi, I served in the Navy from 2000 to 2004 and had the privilege of working aboard 2 LA class subs on 2 missions in the Pacific. At the time, I was in my early 20s, and didn’t really appreciate the experience as much as I feel I should have. These videos have taken me back in time and made me feel the pride and uniqueness of those experiences. Life on a submarine isn’t easy or comfortable, but it is something that very few people who have lived on this planet have had the chance to experience, and should be appreciated as such.
Again, thank you Destin.

Your Cartesian Diver example does not apply to the submarine your are aboard.  The air pressure inside the submarine does not vary with depth so it cannot affect the ballast tanks containing water and air used to trim the boat.  The only time the ballast tanks are affected by depth is when they are blown (valves opened), and at that point the outside water pressure makes contact with the internal pressure of the ballast tanks, and if the ballast engineer did not add enough air pressure to the ballast tank, it will not blow and instead the ballast tanks will have seawater ingress.  The deeper the boat, the more air pressure the engineer will have to add to the ballast tanks to get them to blow at depth.  Generally I like your content, but this example is very sloppy science, something about which a self-proclaimed "rocket engineer" should have known better.  Down-arrow.  Glad your are not the ballast engineer on my submarine!!!!

You really need to go diving .... all that buoyancy stuff?? Eventually you learn not only to use your 'buoyancy' tank (BCD), but more often than not by adjusting the amount of air in your lungs slightly as you breathe (not breath holding - that's bad - simply adjusting your 'full' breath capacity)... as I was told, eventually you'll reach that zen moment where you can drop in the water (say off a boat) and when you hit 20M (or whatever the floor depth is) , stop dead. You learn to micro control and hold angles and depth in current to take pictures - etc.   It's quite an amazing feeling when 100% instinct controls the hover........ MUCH more exciting that your first fin pivot ... hehe -

Nobody mentioned SQUID?
Spherical Quartz Interference Detector.
A gravity-based system to avoid large objects like sea-mounds.
Spinning quartz balls in a network of Josephson Junction transistors that register minute changes in electrical fields.
As the ball spins, local gravity flexes it this way and that; flexing quartz makes an electrostatic field through piezoelectric effect.
The Junctions detect the electrostatic fields and their changes.
By analyzing how the signals changes over time, sensing moving object is fairly simple.
BTW, it can't be jammed, spoofed or detected.
They have been around for 40+ years in declassified form.

Destin,
Ex submariner here.
Test depth is only 1/2 of design depth. In other words, test depth is over a 100% safety factor.
Relax.
Figure, the boat that you were on has a hull made of HY-80 steel. That's 80,000 lbs per square inch tensile strength, and the hull is roughly 3 inches thick. Do the math...

Also, as a boat dives, there really isn't too much of a Cartesian Diver effect. That's because there are actually two different types of sea water tanks on submarines: ballast tanks (which are free flooding from the bottom, and vented via hydraulically controlled valves on the top to flood them or let water in as they let air out; and they're drained by closing the vents, and blowing air into them, thus forcing water out the bottom), and trim tanks which are within the pressure hull, and are filled or emptied via pumps. These are the tanks that get filled or emptied to achieve neutral bouyancy. There is typically one forward, one aft, and one or more amidships. Once a boat is completely submerged, the ballast tank vents are usually left open to avoid trapping air or other gasses in them, and thus affecting the trim. They might be closed in a "rig for ultra quiet" scenario, to avoid the gurgle of escaping gas, but generally they're left open. The neutral bouyancy and zero degree bubble are then achieved by pumping sea water into (or out of) the appropriate trim tanks.

Oh, and there is an upward-looking sonar that can show both the distance to the ice, as well as the thickness of the ice. Strange that no body answered that, because I'm pretty sure that's not classified information. It didn't used to be. Maybe they were just too busy during surfacing ops

Once again Destin,  I want to thank you as a veteran submariner for doing such a great job showing how submarines work.  I wish that the nuclear propulsion wasn't confidential, as that is what I would love to show my family and friends.   One thing you might want to look into is working out how to do something like this with a commercial nuclear power plant.   I don't know how much freedom you would be given,  but I think it would be cool for you to try.  If you want me to look into getting you into the one I work at,  I would be thrilled to try to help.

About your question regarding measuring ice thickness, I believe this is (or can be) done with SONAR. You should get multiple returns on one signal; one where you hit the ice and one where you hit the surface of the ice. With those in hand you should have some idea of the thickness of the ice, since you have some idea of how fast sound travels in water and how fast it travels in ice. With that said, I'm not positive that's actually how they do it.

Transcription of 27:45

"Captain, sir, the ship is ready to vertical surface. I intend to vertically surface the ship."
"Cross-deck, vertically surface the ship."
"Vertically surface the ship, aye sir. Con officer, vertically surface the ship."
"Vertically surface the ship, aye doc. Vertically surface the ship."
"Vertically surface the ship, dive aye."
"Queue launch from MC, vertical surface, vertical surface, vertical surface."
"Number 1 MC, vertical surface, vertical surface, vertical surface. Aye"
"Vertical surface! Vertical surface! Vertical surface!"
"Vertical surface control maneuvering aye"

I love this series and have been following you for years. As a retired Submarine Chief of the Boat and Nuclear Propulsion Plant Operator / Supervisor, who was inspired to submarine service because my Dad was a diesel submarine sailor - I am extremely pleased to know that the Navy selected you for this opportunity. You always do remarkable work, and I love your videos.

By the way, my younger brother was also a Submariner (Sonar Technician), and his son, my nephew, is currently serving in submarines as a Sonar Technician. So many times, I talk with civilians who have no clue what submarine life is about, and I find it difficult to remotely explain what submarine life is like as there is just too much to explain. And you only covered the forward end of the ship as the Engine Room is off limits - and a lot happens back there!

You did an excellent job on this, and I am sure you wish you could have done more. Thank you for all you do to help people become Smarter Every Day!

Gratitude. Sometimes it’s a complex process or idea like the USN sub deep dive or the rocket factory tour with Tory Bruno. Other segments like the clear carburetor piece with your dad where the context of the love and shared curiosity of father and son combined with the beauty of the imagery elevated the piece so that we were gazing through a campfire and seeing bigger things. The craftsmanship of your storytelling is so high without getting in the way. Your heart and Spirit seem to serve you well in drawing our attention to see and understand things while reveling in the wonder that remains.

I often think about those students that love learning about physics, chemistry, biology and math but then are culled out of the next classes that seem defying for those with the discipline, love and predisposition (minds, parents, other) that compel them to stay the course. I see the world increasingly as a STEAM world than a STEM one and your storytelling opens up the science so that even those that practice it daily are stirred to pause and have gratitude for the wonder within their work. Thank you.

Destin, the one thing I wish you had covered (and probably cannot due to security concerns) is how subs navigate under water. While there are subs with view ports or acrylic bubbles that allow you to see out, but most subs don't. Even with the advanced imaging of the sonar dome and sat based navigation, (if I remember correctly) subs primarily navigate with a clock, a map under a piece of glass, a ruler, and a grease pen. It's like trying to drive around town in a car where every window is blacked out, and all you have is the speedometer, a stopwatch, a compass, and a map. You know you're starting out at point X,Y on the map, you want to arrive at point Xdest,Ydest by the end, and you have a series of way points to navigate through. Each time you reach a waypoint, you have to calculate the angle of the next turn and how long you should run in that direction at the set speed you're going. Mess up, and you run aground or into something. Granted, in the deep oceans, running into things isn't too much of a problem. But let's say the mission has the sub in coastal waters where they're trying to slide around commercial shipping, other militaries, and any nosy citizens unobserved.

If you want proof of that, did you notice that the deck officer running the sub during it's surfacing move was using a stop watch?

It is wild how secretive they have to be about limits of capability. If the enemy knows accurate limits they can figure out a method to defeat even far superior technology.  It really gives you a perspective of just how important security is and why spying is such a big deal at all times. If you want an idea about how limitations effect practical application without having to worry about security clearances and military personnel having to avoid talking about certain things, go find some of the guys that are really good at DCS. It is a game called Digital Combat Simulator, and ask them about missile avoidance tactics when flying jets, and about why the performance specs the phblic are given are always so far off of reality.

A few points;

First-(Observation,) I have heard of environments in movies called “Claustrophobic.” For example, the movie “Alien.” Compared to that walk-in closet of a submarine, the Nostromo is a luxurious yacht.

Second-(This is a long one,) in “the Hunt for Red October,” the sonar man Jonesy was said to have a sophisticated music player. It makes sense that the crew would have a “Music Player,” and not a radio. A radio could accidentally transmit, and reveal the position of the sub. A modern-day equivalent of this would be the laptop computer.
I know there is not a wireless system on the boat, but is there a hard wire link to a shipboard server? Such a system would be useful.

Third-How do the military personnel work with civilian scientists on subjects related to climate change, when their political leads are in disagreement with the scientists.

Your example with the eye dropper would only hold true if if ballast tanks were not pressure vessels/open to the atmosphere around them.

As a scuba diver ( and chem eng) I imagine the difference being that of the scuba tank vs that of the BCD ( buoyancy control device thing of it as just a bladder). As demonstrated the buoyancy of the BCD changes significantly with depth. however the buoyancy of the scuba tank does not significantly change with depth sure a little crushing occurs but thats not significant. Same as the buoyancy contributed by the occupied part of the sub would change minimally.

16:22 is a similar concept to what scuba divers experience. Before learning how to scuba dive, i thought that either A, i didn’t have to change my BCD inflation depending on the depth, or B, i would need my BCD less inflated the deeper i went. However it’s the opposite. As i go deeper, i add more air to the BCD to keep myself from sinking all the way to the sea floor.

...Though it'll probably only be accurate to like 40% of the result so maybe it won't be any worse than publicly available data

You mentioned how you speculated that they might have used some bow control device to turn into the "parking space". I don't think this is necessary since you are dealing with low speeds, water, and a rudder that probably has a lot of room for deflection. You can watch videos of small canal boats leave their moorings, and it's incredible what maneuvers can be pulled off in that sort of environment, very different from a cars steering or an airplane rudder. This is probably why the sub can't translate sideways, as just a set of bow thrusters combined with rudder and main engine thrust would allow you to do something very close to that kind of movement.

One thing you got wrong normally the ballast tanks are full of sea water and the trim is adjusted with the internal trim tanks not by putting any air in the ballast tanks at all. They use short bursts of air in the ballast tanks to give the sub enough momentum to surface through the ice. I will tell you this a lot of your assumptions are correct I just won't tell you which ones. BTW served on Fast Attacks in the mid 70's.

I experienced the air compression phenomenon when scuba diving. It's kind of scary, because to descend, you want to let a bit of air out of your BCD to achieve negative buoyancy. Just a bit so you descend slowly, so you can equalize as you go. However, as you descend your air tanks are being compressed, so they displace less water and you start to accelerate. If there aren't many landmarks, or you are diving at night, it can be hard to notice this happening.

Hey Destin. Really interesting to see you experience what happens during a sub dive and surface, and to figure out what's going on with thrust, diving planes and buoyancy.  I used to play around with buoyancy a lot when I was diving a lot in an earlier life time. We used adjustable buoyancy life jackets (ABLJs) to adjust to neutral buoyancy once we'd got to working depth. From there I could control my buoyancy and therefore height in the water by controlling my breathing. By adjust the, say, 30% of the max breath volume that I'm using to be either at the top/full end, or the bottom/empty end of the breath, I changed my buoyancy and would rise or sink in the water column. How about getting the Navy to take you diving? :-)

@16:30

This is so fascinating.
You mention Destin that you'd maintain a certain velocity to ensure you'd have the lift to overcome the buoyancy drop.

That would work yes. But they don't have that luxury if they're a warship.

They're cruising right now from what I understand. Now if they were trying to be sneaky sneaky spying on XYZ then they'd be forced to move slow. How slow I obviously don't know, probably no more than 5ish knots or they'd be making too much noise.

Propeller under water goes "thud thud thud thud thud" after all.

I guess that's why 'silent running' is a full blown procedure and mind set. It isn't just about speed and noise. Especially in the arctic you'd have to deal with the pressure and bouancy woes along with the fact that a dropped spanner could lead to a torpedo being dropped on your head.

26:56 As a former US Navy nuclear reactor operator on an aircraft carrier, this evolution reminded me a lot of an UNREP (Underway Replenishment). For that process, the ship that the carrier is getting supplies from sets and locks their speed. The carrier then approaches the supply ship and has to make tiny corrections to maintain speed. A carrier has 4 screws. The forward reactor controls 1 and 4 (the outside ones) and the aft reactor controls 2 and 3 (the inside ones). One of the two plants (I think it was the forward reactor plant) sets their speed and the throttlemen (the ones that control the throttle valve that feeds steam into the main engines) take their hands off their hand wheels. The after reactor plant then handles the minute changes to speed to keep us alongside the supply vessel. There are times when the bridge orders a change in the number of propeller RPMs 20 times per second, just to keep us alongside. Anyways, I know the sub experience is a lot more intense, but that tiny portion where "NAV" is calling slight bell changes rapidly reminded me of the UNREP.

The company I work for has "stuff" in Prudhoe Bay. Part of me wants to see it and the rest of says nah... Great series!! I listened to the audio book. It was amazing. Also... down in Mobile, Alabama the Battleship Alabama and the submarine Drum are on display (I'm sure that you know that). There was, hopefully still is, an SR71 Blackbird on display. I've been there numerous times. I've taken my kids there and once this weirdness passes I'll take my grandkids there. The Drum has diesel engines on it that are pretty unique. They were made by Fairbanks Morse. They have an upper and lower crankshaft and 2 pistons per cylinder that come very close together to pressurize the diesel / air mixture the pressure that causes the mixture to ignite. In the late 70's and 80's a company converted them to natural gas service and we used them to compress natural gas and sometimes propane. Some were turbocharged. Some were turbo and supercharged. It's a very unique engine. The natural gas engines were called MEP's. Mean Effective Pressure.

I haven't heard the term hoop stress in a while. We use that in the pipeline business.

First, Electric Boat in Groton, CT., makes some amazing boats, always have.
Secondly, while I served in the U.S. Air Force, my step-father, three brother-in-laws, and my brother all rode the boats, and most of my friends all rode the boats. Of course, I used to live just outside of Groton, where not only Electric Boat is, but the U.S., Submarine base is, and where ALL submariners go for their initial training. Today, I live in Washington State, not too far from Subbase Bangor where the Trident missile subs are home based.

And yes, I know who Eugene Flucky is. World War II submarines have always been interesting to me, as was the history of submarines in general. Some might ask why I went in the Air Force versus the Navy and riding the boats. Believe me, it was much better than I did, because it takes a very special kind of person to wear the Dolphins, and I'm not that person. But, I have a great deal of respect for those who do.

Destin, speaking as a fellow mechanical engineer, that rope demonstration was fantastic!
I did some measurements and math on the rope, and worked out that the hull compressed by approximately 6.5mm (1/4") in diameter based on the frequency change in the rope. If I assume a steel hull thickness of 63.5mm (2.5"), that puts the submarine's depth somewhere between 240m - 460m (800ft -1500ft) with the uncertainties that I had in the measurements of the submarines dimensions and starting depth. (thanks Wikipedia) (could be significantly more than this as bracing was not taken into account in the pressure vessel equations)

Hey Destin: at 27:09 you postulate some sort of other motor that can rotate the ship. There is, usually called the Outboard Motor, and usually located near the aft of the ship! It is in fact a retractable, electric motor.

Edit: Now that the series is over, I'm just sad they never let you film back aft (they nearly never do). Did you at least get to visit back aft? Usually they don't let riders back aft unless they've been cleared for radiation work, but I would hate for you to miss out on seeing all of the really cool mechanical and electrical stuff back there. And realistically your dose would for doing so would have been almost nothing, probably 0 to 2 mrem depending on how long and exactly where you stood (you'd only get 2 mrem if you were trying to get irradiated). In my 3.5 years on my sub I totaled 1500 mrem, and that's with upwards of 50% of my time back aft.

For the edification of all:


Formal communications on the boat require a verbatim repeat back followed by acknowledgement in this format "Hey [YOU] it's [ME]"

For example: "Maneuvering, Con: Ahead 2/3(rds)"

"Ahead 2/3(rds), Maneuvering, Con, aye."

05:05 onward is a great example of this ongoing chain of comms... Dive gets an order and passes that to the Chief of the Watch... Obviously, when it's an order, it's the whole thing, but when it's just reports and time is of the essence, it gets cut down.

Hope you learned something. 😀

A word about these submariners (side fact: they call themselves 'sub mah-reen ers', not 'sub mare-in ers', also subs are boats, carriers are ships) Boat Captains are the most amazing people that you'll never hear about. You can have 3 Engineering degrees and know how every system on the boat works down to the bolt, but never come close to being a Boat Captain. You can be as good at managing people as a fortune 500 CEO, but never come close to being a Boat Captain. You can be cool as a cucumber while under enormous stress while being shot at, but never come close to being a Boat Captain. You can be such a great strategist that you're a chess master, but never come close to being a Boat Captain. If you want to be a Boat Captain you'll have to be ALL those things, without exception. They are (mostly) extraordinarily complex and eccentric individuals, and very daunting to interact with.

Where each Boat Captain is the equivalent of Mozart, each member of the crew is as skilled as a 1st chair in the Vienna Philharmonic. Now, you're saying to yourself "how is that possible, how do they find those people?" The answer is the Dolphin Pin. The Cook from a U.S. Navy boat could blow your mind with their level knowledge. Everyone aboard who has any level of responsibility must have their Dolphins. To get that pin is nearly impossible. Imagine what you went through to get your college degree.. but you have 6 majors and have to study 18hrs a day 7days a week for months at a time with no break. If you don't get your Dolphins you can't stay on the boat. The Navy will find something easier for you to do. That's one reason we're so much better than the competition... it's not even close. No CNN, not even the Russians.

Put it this way; Destin showed that there are an amazing number of complexities and variables involved with buoyancy. These people get it right 100% of the time.. and they can do it while getting shot at or while there's a fire aboard... 100% of the time. Your U.S. Navy Submariners are so skilled, and our equipment is so capable, that we routinely follow enemy subs, *right on their tail*, for weeks without them knowing it. One author described Subsurface Warfare as "knife fighting in a phonebooth while blindfolded ... in slow motion". With that in mind, the U.S. Navy is Bruce Lee.

There are a few audio books that I'd recommend in addition to Thunder Down Below. They're all on Audible. What you learn will blow you away :
Blind Man's Bluff: The Untold Story of American Submarine Espionage
Red November: Inside the Secret U.S.-Soviet Submarine War
Stalking the Red Bear: The True Story of a U.S. Cold War Submarine's Covert Operations Against the Soviet Union
Making a Submarine Officer: A Story of the USS San Francisco (SSN 711)

As a proud former submariner (MMN2/ELT), thank you, thank you, thank you for creating and sharing this incredible "deep dive" series highlighting an area of the military that's remains near and dear to my heart 40 years after departing USS Will Rogers (SSBN 659).

While Artic excursions weren't part of any mission in which I participated, we trained for it, and it was very interesting to gain some insight into how things are done on newer boats.

The tying of a string across the beam is part of a traditional welcome to new crew members. It can be unnerving to go deep, but after you do it a few times, you take it all in stride.

For those the least bit interested in submarines, I'd encourage them to just go for it. It's a lot of hard work, but it's so worth it. It's training and experience unlike anywhere else on earth and completed by a very small number of people.

The one thing this series has taught me...
Is that the Seaview from Voyage to the Bottom of the Sea is a total fabrication!
Not that I ever once believed that the futuristic submarine of the far off future of ten years later in the 1970s would ever be believable, but the technology of a modern sub in 2021 doesn't even allow half as much room as was available on the Seaview. That, or the Seaview is bigger than we could even possibly imagine. Like a full blown Battleship has been submerged, and even then that's probably hopelessly smaller compared to the amount of space on deck aboard the Seaview. That bridge was so small, you guys were packed in there with no room whatsoever, and Voyage to the Bottom of the Sea is doing it with the same amount of people spread out across the length of a house. It's comical.
But this was a fascinating series, and it's cool to see how much freedom you were allowed like going inside a torpedo tube, showing hygienic routines, and ice cream on waffles. If you had been told what to shoot, it would not have nearly been as compelling, and a lot less fun to learn.

You can't do that with solely bouyancy as that operates vertically, not axially.

16:40 This is also a very dangerous phenomenon that affects scuba divers. After a certain critical depth, you enter a feedback loop of more pressure leading to less buoyancy leading to more depth, rinse and repeat. An unattentive diver may sink so fast that they might not be able to recover.
